Award.AwardTitle: Characterization and Removal of Galactic Dust Foreground from Measurements of the Polarization of the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation
Award.AbstractNarration: The proposal seeks funding to begin a research effort on characterizing and extracting galactic dust emissions from the data that will be collected by the NASA-funded Antarctic Long Duration Balloon-borne (LDB) ?E and B Experiment? (EBEX). A leading cosmological paradigm for the beginning and evolution of the Universe posits a period of Inflation shortly after the Big Bang. Inflation generated primordial gravitational waves in the Universe that imprinted a distinct signature called the "B-mode signal" on the polarization of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) radiation. This signal is extremely weak, around 100 microKelvins or smaller, and astrophysical foregrounds such as polarized emission from galactic dust and synchrotron radiation swamp the Inflationary signal over most of the sky. The EBEX balloon payload will have the sensitivity to detect the B-mode signal if it is stronger than 1/10 of the current theoretical upper limit. The balloon observations will be carried out in frequency bands between 150 and 410 GHz. The higher end of this band is not accessible from the ground; thus, EBEX can provide valuable information on the properties of galactic dust emissions. This information is critical for all the CMB experiments searching for the Inflationary signal. EBEX is currently awaiting its flight from Antarctica in the austral summer of 2010/2011. The requested funds will be used to support a post-doctoral fellow and a graduate student to work on the characterization and extraction of galactic dust foregrounds from the EBEX data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a postdoctoral researcher (Ben Gold) and a graduate student (Chaoyun Bao) over the course of three years to develop techniques to assess the level of foreground contamination in measurement of the polarization of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB). Specifically, we concentrated on the difficult problem of assessing the level of galactic dust contamination in experiments that use a particular optical element called 'an Achromatic Half-Wave Plate' (AHWP).

A common technique for measuring small signals is to design the experiment to modulate (vary) the wanted signal with some known frequency, so that it can be separated from sources of noise (which are not modulated). Some experiments that measure the CMB use an AHWP to modulate the incident signal, but the use of the AHWP also changes the properties of the incident polarized signal. The changes depend on the intensity spectrum of this signal.The intensity spectrum of the CMB is well known, so the effect of a well specified AHWP can be calculated. But measurements of the polarization of the CMB over most sections of the sky also contain galactic signals, specifically galactic dust, when the observations are above 100 GHz. the intensity spectrum of galactic dust is not very well know. Therefore to isolate and remove the component due to polarized galactic dust is a challenge when the experiment uses an AHWP.

Gold and Bao developed a theoretical framework to handle such challenges. Using the theoretical framework, they implemented an end-to-end technique to characterize the emission due to polarized galactic dust that has an unknown spectrum and is observed with an experiment that uses an AHWP. They simulated real observations that mimic the observation of an existing balloon experiment (EBEX) and ran the algorithms on the simulated data. They showed the underlying true emission from the CMB is recovered with small increase in error above that contributed by instrumental noise. The results were published in the Astrophysical Journal.

In addition, Gold took on a leading role coordinating the data analysis for EBEX, which is a NASA-funded balloon-borne telescope. With synergy from this grant, he also developed end-to-end software to support the project. 

During the time of this award, the grantees engaged in a number of training and development activities.  Bao travelled to a workshop in Paris and worked with several of our overseas collaborators.   Both Gold and Bao demonstrated science effects and explained their project at the Minnesota State Fair, which has the highest daily attendance in the country. They have also each engaged in the 'Multicultural Scientist STEM Academy', and the University of Minnesota's 'Science Family Fun Fair'. Gold also enrolled in the University of Minnesota's "Preparing Future Faculty" program.
